newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Caspian Pipeline group to sign "final" deal Friday.
newsitem.headline: Caspian Pipeline group to sign "final" deal Friday.

text.p: The Caspian Pipeline Consortium (CPC), planning to build an oil pipeline from Kazakhstan to Russia, is due to sign what it calls a "final agreement" on the deal later on Friday, the company said in a statement.
The agreement will allow full project financing and contruction on the $2-billion project to proceed, it added.
CPC will build a 1,500 km (940 mile) pipeline from Kazakhstan's Tengiz oilfield to Russia's Black Sea oil export outlet of Novorossiisk.
The consortium plans to build a pipeline with an initial capacity of 28 million tonnes a year (560,000 barrels per day) and a peak of 67 million tonnes a year (1.34 million bpd).

Chevron Corp owns 15 percent of CPC, Russia's LUKoil 12.5 percent, Mobil Corp and Russia's Rosneft 7.5 percent each, BG Plc and Italy's Agip SpA two percent each, and Oryx Energy Company and Kazakhstan's Munaigaz 1.75 percent each.
The remaining 50 percent is divided between Russia (24 percent), Kazakhstan (19 percent) and Oman (seven percent).
The final division of the Russian government share in the project has yet to be decided.
Rosneft, LUKoil and Russian oil pipeline monopoly Transneft are known to be competing for the stake.
